title: House Panel Starts Debate on Articles of Impeachment
summary: Democrats intend to send charges to full House next week. WASHINGTON-The House Judiciary Committee began debating two articles of impeachment aimed at President Trump on Wednesday night, planning to vote on the charges Thursday and send the measure to the full House for approval next week.

title: A Massive European-Style Estate in Bel-Air
summary: Owned by the late billionaire Univision Chairman Jerry Perenchio, the property dates back to the 1930s and comes with elaborate manicured gardens.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Lachlan Murdoch Sets L.A. Record by Paying $150 Million for a Château-Style Mansion
summary: Once listed for $350 million, the Bel-Air estate of late media tycoon A. Jerrold Perenchio is the second priciest home ever to have traded in the U.S.. Lachlan Murdoch, media executive and son of media mogul Rupert Murdoch, has paid roughly $150 million for Chartwell, a Bel-Air estate, according to people familiar with the deal.

title: India Says Path to Citizenship Will Get Easier, but Muslims See a Hindu Plot
summary: Parliament passes bill that furthers Hindu-nationalist agenda of Prime Minister Modi's party. NEW DELHI-India's legislature established a path to citizenship that excludes Muslim illegal immigrants, as Prime Minister Narendra Modi leverages his re-election victory to push through contentious policies that Hindu nationalists have pursued for decades.

title: Prosecutors Say Giuliani Associate Parnas Hid Income, Should Be Detained
summary: Before Parnas' arrest, a bank account in his wife's name received $1 million from Russian account. Federal prosecutors have asked a judge to revoke bail for Lev Parnas, saying the associate of Rudy Giuliani's has lied to authorities about his assets and income and should be detained while awaiting trial.

title: Deadly Jersey City Attack Rattles Community
summary: Neighborhood of Jews and African-Americans is left reeling after shooters kill four people. JERSEY CITY, N.J.-The day after two assailants shot up a kosher grocery and fired hundreds of rounds during an hourslong standoff with police here, a restoration crew boarded up the gaping hole where the storefront's glass window had been shattered.

title: Harvey Weinstein, Ex-Associates, Accusers Reach Tentative $47 Million Settlement
summary: About $25 million will compensate women who accused the Hollywood producer of sexual misconduct. Harvey Weinstein, his former associates, insurers and accusers have reached a nearly $47 million tentative settlement of almost all the civil cases pending against him, about $25 million of which will compensate women who have accused the Hollywood producer of sexual misconduct, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Why China's Big Bank Listing Didn't Pop
summary: An arcane rule prevents the country's state-owned companies from pricing their stock below book value, stifling the IPO market. Mainland China's biggest stock-market listing this year has gotten an unusually tepid reception, adding to the funding challenges faced by the country's beleaguered banking system.

title: Republicans Condemn FBI's Use of Surveillance Powers
summary: Self-described security hawks now say they see major problems in surveillance law. WASHINGTON-One by one, Republican senators expressed outrage Wednesday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had committed errors in how it sought and obtained surveillance on a former Trump campaign adviser, describing the findings contained in a new inspector general report as evidence of alarming privacy violations that could be wielded against any American.

title: House Passes Bill Providing Citizenship Path for Immigrant Farmworkers
summary: Despite bill's bipartisan support in House, it is unlikely to be taken up for a vote in Republican-controlled Senate. WASHINGTON-The House passed a bill on Wednesday providing a path to citizenship for the more than one million farmworkers estimated to be in the U.S. illegally on a 260-165 vote, with 34 Republicans voting in favor of the deal.

title: New York City Boosts Security After Deadly Shooting in Jersey City
summary: The mayor directs the NYPD to assign hundreds of officers to dozens of crucial locations in Jewish communities. New York City is increasing security measures at potential terror targets following the deadly shootings at a Kosher market in Jersey City, N.J., that may have been motivated by anti-Semitism, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Wednesday.

title: FAA Knew Boeing's 737 MAX Was Risky but Allowed Flights
summary: House committee hearing focuses on FAA and Boeing moves between the tragedies. U.S. regulators decided to allow Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX jet to keep flying after its first fatal crash last fall even when their own analysis indicated it could become one of the most accident-prone airliners in decades without design changes.

title: House Passes Bill Including Paid Parental Leave for Federal Workers
summary: The $738 billion legislation also calls for creation of the Space Force and seeks to check Russia's energy ambitions. WASHINGTON-The House approved a bill Wednesday that includes paid parental leave for federal workers, the creation of the U.S. Space Force and new sanctions related to Russia's energy ambitions.

title: Shooters Targeted Kosher Grocery Store, Jersey City Mayor Says
summary: Two of the victims worked at the store, and a third was a customer; officials identify the shooters as David Anderson and Francine Graham. JERSEY CITY, N.J.-The two shooters who killed four people in an hourslong rampage here supported anti-Semitic groups online and are the lead suspects in the recent murder of an Uber driver, officials said, adding new twists to a crime that shook a city that publicly heralds welcoming immigrants and diversity.

title: Dominion Energy Turns to Cow Manure in Gas Pact
summary: Deal is the latest venture between livestock concerns and power producers to generate gas from animal waste. Dominion Energy Inc. has struck a $200 million pact with a renewable energy producer and the Dairy Farmers of America Inc. to extract natural gas from cow manure.

title: Macron Returns to the Barricades
summary: The French president faces down the streets over pension reform.. Strikes by French trade unions usually mean a politician is doing something right. So it is after a week of nationwide protests against President Emmanuel Macron's proposed overhaul of the country's creaking pension system.

title: Anti-Semitism, Real and Imagined
summary: Worry about murders in Jersey City, not Trump's executive order.. Tuesday's murder of three people in a kosher grocery store in Jersey City, New Jersey, now appears to have been an anti-Semitic attack, with the mayor saying the suspects targeted the market frequented by Hasidic Jews. The police shootout began "with an attack on civilians in the store," according to the city's director of public safety. News reports say one of the alleged shooters may have been a member of the conspiratorial Black Hebrew Israelites and had anti-Semitic social-media posts.

title: The Zombie Medical Device Tax
summary: Another of the undead from ObamaCare may soon reappear.. Republicans and Democrats are trying to cobble together an end-of-year spending bill. But even if Members can't agree on extending most special-interest subsidies-and we hope they don't-they should stop a return of the destructive ObamaCare medical device tax in January.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Impeachment
summary: The Democratic grounds for ousting Trump are weak-and damaging to constitutional norms.. So that's it? That's all there is? After all the talk of obstruction of justice, collusion with Russia, bribery, extortion, profiting from the Presidency, and more, House Democrats have reduced their articles of impeachment against President Trump to two: abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. Honey, we shrunk the impeachment.

title: Michael Cohen Asks Judge to Trim Prison Sentence
summary: Former personal lawyer to President Trump is serving three years after pleading guilty to host of federal crimes in 2018. Lawyers for Michael Cohen asked a judge to reduce the three-year prison sentence President Trump's former personal attorney is serving, citing his continued efforts to cooperate with law enforcement even as they accuse federal prosecutors of acting in bad faith by refusing to engage with Mr. Cohen.

title: Florida Base Shooter's Social Media Reflects Radical Views
summary: Twitter posts believed to be the gunman's show militancy dating back to 2015, raising vetting questions. The Saudi air force member who shot dead three people last week on a naval base in Florida expressed extreme political views on Twitter in posts dating back to 2015, according to excerpts of an internal Saudi government report.

title: Nestlé's Full-Fat Ice-Cream Sale Comes Later
summary: Swiss food company has sold U.S. ice-cream brands including Häagen-Dazs for $4 billion to an existing joint venture with a private equity company. Nestlé 's latest deal should help it milk the softening ice-cream business for private-equity style returns, perhaps ahead of a potential initial public offering in a few years' time.

title: Blackface, Slurs and the Player Who Brought a Racial Reckoning to Hockey
summary: Akim Aliu's story of enduring racism inside hockey includes an incident in which a minor-league team staffer dressed up as him in blackface. Akim Aliu had been a member of the Colorado Eagles, a minor-league hockey team, for just a small part of the season in 2011 when he received an invitation to the team's Halloween party. The team's players, staff, management and even their families would be there.

title: Immigrant Arrests Fell in 2019 as Deportations Rose
summary: Government statistics reflect a shift in Trump administration priorities toward enforcement at the border. U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement made about 143,000 arrests in the 2019 fiscal year, the agency said Wednesday, a 10% decline from the previous year, marking the lowest number of arrests to date under the Trump administration.

title: DOJ Watchdog Testifies About His Report on FBI's Russia Probe
summary: Inspector General Michael Horowitz says neither William Barr nor prosecutor John Durham provided evidence to counter his finding the FBI inquiry had an adequate basis. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department's inspector general on Wednesday revealed new details about an unusual disagreement among top department officials over the propriety of the FBI's Russia investigation, as the political fallout over the bureau's actions during the 2016 campaign intensified on Capitol Hill.

title: Price Controls Would Stifle Biotech Innovation
summary: A House price-control bill would do the most damage to transformative and life-saving medications.. Victoria Gray of Mississippi recently became the first U.S. patient with a genetic disorder to be treated using the Crispr gene-editing technique. Doctors used a novel drug to overwrite the function of a faulty gene that gave rise to her sickle-cell disease. Advances in life science can define this century, but policy makers must resist the urge to adopt policies that impose price controls and punish drugmakers for taking risks.

title: I'm Partial to Impartiality
summary: The ructions of the Trump presidency have made it impossible to maintain a cool head about politics.. When the history of the Trump administration is written, I hope the fact-and I believe it is a fact-that the president made it all but impossible to remain politically impartial is included. Donald Trump was a room-divider. Long-held friendships broke down in disagreement about him. Families split up. He made Richard Nixon, who in his day could arouse strong political passions, seem like Mister Rogers.

title: Mom and Pop Aren't Money Launderers
summary: The Corporate Transparency Act is an onerous remedy to an elusive problem.. We can all agree that money laundering-turning ill-gotten gains into usable cash-should be prevented, but should American small businesses bear the costs of uncovering it? Banks, securities firms and other financial institutions likely to be enlisted in money-laundering schemes are already covered by know-your-customer and other rules that require them to report suspicious transactions. These are the most effective ways to catch the principal offenders.

title: What Horowitz Actually Debunked
summary: The report refers 19 times to Crossfire Hurricane's threat to 'constitutionally protected activity,' including the First Amendment.. The battles between President Trump, the Democrats and the media have begun to dispirit a populace that thinks the Trump Wars have little to do with them or the country's real needs. The public is right-but the war won't stop.

title: Turkey Says It Might Retaliate Over New U.S. Sanctions
summary: Foreign minister said adoption of sanctions could jeopardize U.S. access to military installations in Turkey. WASHINGTON-The Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday advanced bipartisan legislation that would punish Turkey for its purchase of a Russian anti-aircraft missile system and alleged crimes against Syrian Kurds, a measure that drew the ire of Turkish officials.

title: Independents Are Impeachment Skeptics
summary: They see partisan bickering, hypocrisy and a waste of time.. 'What the heck is going on?"

title: 'Ministry of Darkness' Review: An Intellect of Empire
summary: Sergei Uvarov was a singular ﬁgure who exercised a profound influence on Russian education and thought.. Russian intellectual historians usually are drawn to figures who can be readily classified-as revolutionaries or reactionaries, or as Slavophiles or Westernizers-while neglecting those who cannot. In her splendid book "Ministry of Darkness," Lesley Chamberlain instead trains her attention on Sergei Uvarov (1786-1855), a paradoxical figure so original as to transcend all familiar categories. Ms. Chamberlain, an independent historian and novelist, persuasively shows how he nevertheless exercised a profound influence on Russian education and thought.

title: Dubious Stats Fuel Attack on Jewish Schools
summary: Hasidim have higher measured poverty because their families tend to be large.. Critics of New York's yeshivas often point to elevated poverty rates among Hasidim as proof that the Jewish schools fail to educate their students properly. "Given this lack of education, it is not surprising that 43% of Hasidic households in New York City are poor," Lehigh University scholar Dena Daviswrote in these pages last year.

title: FAA Probes Alleged Production Issues at Boeing Plant
summary: Retired manager tells Congress the plane maker and regulators ignored quality-problem warnings. The Federal Aviation Administration said it is investigating alleged production issues at a Boeing Co. factory near Seattle, where the plane maker assembles the 737 MAX. The disclosure followed testimony from a retired manager who told a congressional committee he had warned repeatedly about quality problems arising from pressure to produce the aircraft more quickly.

title: Trump's Era of Judicial Excellence
summary: Leftists say the President assaults the rule of law but acknowledge he's appointed a highly qualified group to defend it.. Most media pundits have given up trying to make the case that President Donald Trump is an authoritarian tyrant. Now they must grudgingly admit how much he's done to bolster the rule of law.

title: Confirmation Hearing Is Smooth for Nominee to Lead Indian Health Agency
summary: Career health-service official recently has picked up support of many Native American tribes. President Trump's nominee to lead the Indian Health Service breezed through a Senate confirmation hearing Wednesday, facing few tough questions from the handful of lawmakers who were present.

title: Trump Signs Executive Order Targeting Anti-Semitism on College Campuses
summary: The order would expand the federal government's definition of anti-Semitism. WASHINGTON-With a White House Hanukkah reception as the backdrop, President Trump signed an executive order aimed at combating anti-Semitism on college campuses.

title: Lululemon Leans Into Men's Apparel as Segment Expands
summary: Activewear company famous for pricey yoga pants says sales of men's garments grew 38% in latest quarter. Lululemon Athletica Inc. built its brand by convincing women to wear its pricey yoga pants even when they weren't headed to the gym. These days, the company says its most promising customers are men.

title: U.S. Imposes New Sanctions Against Companies Aiding Iran
summary: Shippers are accused of sending Iranian arms to Yemen's rebels, helping Iran's nuclear program. WASHINGTON-The U.S. on Wednesday blacklisted a series of companies it accused of helping Iran transport weaponry to regional militia groups, including missile parts to Houthi rebels in Yemen.

title: Harold Hamm, Shale Pioneer, Steps Down as CEO of Continental Resources
summary: His successor, William Berry, has served on Continental's board since 2014; changes take effect Jan. 1. Billionaire shale drilling pioneer Harold Hamm is retiring as chief executive of the oil-and-gas company he founded, Continental Resources Inc.

title: Powell Confident About Year-End, but Says Fed Asset Buying Open to Change
summary: Purchasing longer-dated Treasurys is one possibility for the central bank. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said Wednesday the central bank's three-month effort to restore calm to financial markets is working, but he also signaled a willingness to be flexible if events require it, including buying longer-dated Treasurys.

title: Inflation Isn't Likely to Take Off Anytime Soon
summary: Economists point to subdued price, labor cost increases despite low unemployment and the trade war. WASHINGTON-Inflation isn't likely to take off anytime soon, recent readings on prices and labor costs show.

title: Russia's Gas Pipeline Faces Sanctions Under U.S. Defense Bill
summary: U.S. lawmakers aim to halt $10.5 billion project, Nord Stream 2, by targeting key contractors. U.S. lawmakers are pushing ahead with enactment of new sanctions meant to prevent the completion of a new pipeline constructed to carry Russian natural gas to Germany, beneath the Baltic Sea.

title: New York State GOP Senators Face Steeper Climb to Regain Seats
summary: Mounting retirements add to challenges for Republican lawmakers in 2020 after Democrats consolidated power in Albany. New York state Senate Minority Leader John Flanagan acknowledged Wednesday that he faces a steep path to retake the chamber majority next year, especially with many of his GOP colleagues not seeking re-election.

title: Nothing Is Sacred for New Leader of Nation's Largest Pension Fund
summary: Big changes by Calpers investment chief in his first year reflect latitude given to him to remake the fund at time of high pension costs and low interest rates. It didn't take Yu Ben Meng long to find problems at the nation's largest pension fund.

title: Judge Blocks Military Funding for Border Wall
summary: Ruling in California is second such decision in two days. A federal judge ruled the Trump administration couldn't use billions of dollars in military-construction funding to pay for a southern U.S. border wall, the second such decision in two days.

title: U.S. Stocks Gain After Fed Decision
summary: Investors are braced for a busy few days as the U.S. and European central banks hold policy meetings. Stocks rose after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates steady and indicated no intention of raising them soon.

title: The Horror of Being a Woman (in the Movies)
summary: 'Black Christmas' is one of several horror releases helmed by women directors that are updating old tropes and finding new ways to thrill. In "Black Christmas," a slasher flick out this Friday, a group of sorority sisters are stalked and gruesomely picked off by a mysterious shadow figure right before Christmas break.

title: Israel Faces Third Consecutive Vote After Parliament Deadline Passes
summary: New election, which comes after no party was able to form a government, provides a lifeline for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. TEL AVIV-Israel will hold a third election in less than a year after lawmakers missed a deadline to find a consensus candidate to form a government, prolonging months of political stalemate at a time when the country faces threats ranging from Iran to militants in Gaza to an uncertain economy.

title: Fiat Chrysler Workers Approve New Contract, Ending Detroit Labor Talks
summary: UAW negotiated deals with GM, Ford, Fiat Chrysler amid ongoing federal probe. A lengthy round of labor talks in Detroit has ended after the United Auto Workers said it secured a new four-year contract with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV, the last of three deals negotiated this year by the union.

title: The Best Art of 2019: Where Knowledge and Beauty Meet
summary: Resume Subscription. American museums continued to mount striking temporary exhibitions that combined compelling ideas, groundbreaking scholarship and remarkable, often stunning objects. High points of the past year included everything from medieval Japanese devotional works to sculpture by a contemporary master.

title: Treasury Yields Finish Lower After Fed Decision
summary: Ecuador bonds rally after passage of tax-overhaul bill. U.S. government-bond yields dropped after the Federal Reserve held interest rates steady and signaled the central bank was unlikely to raise them soon.

title: Home Depot Gives Cautious Outlook for 2020
summary: Retailer forecasts same-store sales could fall below 4% next year. Home Depot Inc. tempered its sales targets for next year, saying the long U.S. economic expansion is expected to cool and the home-improvement chain will need more time for some investments to pay off in sales gains.

title: Oil Slips After OPEC, EIA Reports Forecast Robust Supply
summary: The projections say that the world will remain flooded with oil into next year. Oil prices declined after data from OPEC and the U.S. signaled the world will remain flooded with oil into next year.

title: Shares of Oil Giants Fall After Chevron's $10 Billion Charge
summary: Global supply glut, mounting worries about demand for fossil fuels have weighed on energy prices, shares of producers. Shares of big oil and gas producers dropped Wednesday after Chevron Corp. wrote down the value of its assets by more than $10 billion and lowered its forecast for commodity prices.

title: 'Bombshell': Explosive Potential Defused
summary: Charlize Theron, Nicole Kidman and Margot Robbie play women at Fox News who struggle to bring the company's CEO, Roger Ailes, to public account for sexual harassment.. By all rights, "Bombshell" ought to be edifying and gratifying, as well as great fun. We get to watch three gifted stars-Charlize Theron, Nicole Kidman and Margot Robbie-play women at Fox News as they struggle, in 2015 and 2016, to bring the company's CEO, Roger Ailes, to public account for sexual harassment. The narrative takes us behind the scenes at the channel during a time of high drama, when Donald Trump's candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination has suddenly caught fire. By all wrongs, though-beginning with a single-minded script and clumsy direction-a movie with a compelling story to tell turns into a blunt-force polemic that can't stop hammering its message home. The only thing that's missing is a chyron at the bottom of the screen constantly flashing BREAKING NEWS-THIS IS ABOUT A POWERFUL MAN BEHAVING DESPICABLY TOWARD WOMEN. That's what it intends to be, of course, yet it's seldom anything more-no surprises and precious little human resonance.

title: All the Fed Wants for Christmas Is 2% Inflation
summary: The Federal Reserve wants to let inflation run hot for a while, but you can't always get what you want. The Federal Reserve is bent on inflation heading higher. That doesn't mean it can do much about it.

title: NYC Subway Line Falters in Light Snow
summary: MTA demands contractor fix issue with new signal system before next band of winter weather. A new signal system meant to speed trains on one of New York City's busiest subway lines can't handle winter weather.

title: JPMorgan Takes Aim at Rivals in Wealth Business Revamp
summary: Banking giant run by Jamie Dimon taps marketing chief to run new U.S. wealth unit. JPMorgan Chase & Co. is taking a bigger swing at wealth management, revamping its business units in an effort to better compete with big-bank rivals such as Morgan Stanley .

title: Treasury Staffer Linked to College-Admissions Cheating Scandal Resigns
summary: Prosecutors say James Littlefair's mother, who has agreed to plead guilty to fraud conspiracy, paid someone else to take his online classes. A Treasury Department staffer has resigned after his mother, Karen Littlefair, agreed to plead guilty Monday to a charge that she hired an employee of disgraced college counselor William "Rick" Singer to take online classes for him so he could graduate from Georgetown University.

title: JPMorgan CIO Says AI Holds Promise for Helping People Save
summary: The bank is sitting on a huge amount of data that could feed into AI-based services, Lori Beer says. NEW YORK- JPMorgan Chase & Co. Chief Information Officer Lori Beer said artificial intelligence could help the bank develop new products and services for helping people build retirement savings, among other things.

title: 'New Work for Goldberg Variations' Review: Bach in Motion
summary: A collaboration between choreographer Pam Tanowitz and pianist Simone Dinnerstein at the Joyce adds a physical dimension to the demanding keyboard composition..

title: Bipartisan Support for New Nafta Is Rare Achievement in Trade Policy
summary: Labor, Democratic backing don't guarantee support for other trade deals, but fulfill goal of top U.S. negotiator. With the rewrite of the North American Free Trade Agreement, President Trump seems to have won broad support for a major trade deal from Democrats and organized labor. Neither President Clinton nor President Obama could make such a claim.

title: Judge Upholds South Carolina GOP's Decision Not to Hold 2020 Presidential Primary
summary: Move taken by several states to erect hurdles for the long-shot candidates challenging Trump. COLUMBIA, S.C.-A judge on Wednesday upheld the South Carolina Republican Party's decision not to hold a 2020 presidential primary, a move taken by several states in erecting hurdles for the long-shot candidates challenging President Trump.

title: A New Wealth Tax In the Age of Consumption?
summary: We should abandon a tax system based on malleable definitions of income (and wealth) and adopting a tax system anchored in the consumption expenditures that comprise more than 70% of U.S. GDP.. In "Wealth Tax Is a Decent Idea, Though Probably Unconstitutional" (op-ed, Dec. 6), Prof. Alan Blinder explains at length how the federal government could collect a possible wealth tax and fight plutocracy. However, he doesn't define plutocracy, nor explain why Article 1 of the Constitution is problematic. Nor does he explain how the additional revenue will improve economic conditions for average Americans or reduce inequality across the population.

title: Interagency: How Adult Governments Work
summary: The interagency isn't a long-running cabal but more like a series of ad hoc committees which typically bring together both political appointees and career government officials to help form policy for the executive branch.. Carl J. Schramm's "'The Interagency' Isn't Supposed to Rule" (op-ed, Dec. 5) reads like it was written by someone who has never participated in the process. The interagency isn't a long-running cabal but more like a series of ad hoc committees which typically bring together political appointees and career government officials to form policy for the executive branch. Policy disputes between the departments or agencies are ironed out in this process, sometimes at the cabinet or deputy cabinet level-positions usually held by the president's appointees.

title: Qualcomm, 5G, Security and Patent Wars
summary: Allowing others to erode Qualcomm's patents weakens the U.S. in the international 5G race and makes it far more likely that Huawei will overtake our lead.. Former Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff argues that Qualcomm 's dominant status in the 5G technology arena creates national security vulnerabilities by perpetuating a "monoculture risk," and, furthermore, that the U.S. government, in the name of protecting national security, is working overtime to protect Qualcomm from competition ("Qualcomm's Monopoly Imperils National Security," op-ed, Nov. 25).

title: Former Executive at Credit Suisse Venture Says She Was Spied On
summary: Colleen Graham told a U.S. labor court she was retaliated against over an accounting issue, a claim Credit Suisse denies. A former Credit Suisse Group AG executive has told top bank executives and U.S. and Swiss authorities she believes she was put under surveillance in July 2017 while in a dispute with the bank, two years before a separate spying scandal rocked Credit Suisse.

title: Distribute Fed Education Money Directly to Teachers
summary: The biggest factor in a student's success is a skilled teacher. But the average teacher quits after five years, many because they don't earn enough.. Regarding Michael Q. McShane and Jason Bedrick's "Warren's Insight on Teacher Pay" (op-ed, Dec. 5): Sen. Elizabeth Warren's revelation about federal funding for child-development centers-"somehow it all went to the state government and never made it down" to teachers and children-hit home with this school-district governing-board member. The biggest factor in a student's success is a skilled teacher. But the average teacher quits after five years, many because teachers don't earn enough.

title: MLB Study Finds Lower Seam Height on Baseballs Behind Power Surge
summary: Report dismisses theory that manufacturer Rawlings intentionally 'juiced' baseballs to generate offense. SAN DIEGO-Baseballs with a lower seam height coupled with a "change in player behavior" were among the primary causes of the power surge that resulted in players hitting a record 6,776 home runs in 2019, a panel of scientists commissioned by Major League Baseball to study the issue said Wednesday.

title: Aramco Shares Rise 10% After World's Biggest Listing
summary: Shares hit an upward limit set by the Saudi exchange. DUBAI-Aramco shares rose 10% in Riyadh on Wednesday, quickly touching their upward limit, as investors in Saudi Arabia rushed to buy a piece of the world's largest initial public offering.

title: French Unions Pledge More Protests After Government Describes Pension Overhaul
summary: Push for workers to retire later and other proposals draw fire from labor leaders. PARIS-A week into a crippling nationwide strike, French President Emmanuel Macron's government unveiled details of its plan to overhaul the pension system, triggering a rebuke from union leaders who vowed to dig in for a prolonged fight.

summary: Injunction against streaming giant marks win for studios that had sued Netflix over claims it poached talent under contract. summary: Regulators say investigations and improvements take time; consumer advocates push for swifter response. E. coli illnesses linked to romaine lettuce show how U.S. regulators continue to struggle with identifying which farms spark an outbreak and stopping it from spreading.

summary: Game retailer's sales plunge as market awaits new Xbox and PlayStation consoles. There is probably no great time these days to be in the videogame retail business, but some times are definitely worse than others.

summary: Settlement with FTC requires for-profit college, which admits no wrongdoing, to cancel $141 million in student debt. The University of Phoenix has agreed to pay $191 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it used deceptive marketing to recruit students by touting relationships with high-profile companies.

title: Democrats' January Plans Scrambled by Likely Impeachment Trial
summary: The party is working on a contingency plan in case its January debate conflicts with a Senate trial. WASHINGTON-Plans for a Democratic presidential debate in January have been complicated by the expected Senate impeachment trial of President Trump, which could tie up several 2020 hopefuls during the final stretch before the Iowa caucuses.

title: Northern California Power Outages Could Soar If Aging Lines Aren't Replaced, PG&E Study Finds
summary: PG&E's current rate of line replacement won't be able to prevent a surge of failures due to effects of aging, researchers at Georgia Tech found. Sustained power outages caused by electric-wire failures in Northern California could double or even quadruple in years to come unless PG&E Corp. steps up its replacement of aging equipment, according to a utility-commissioned analysis.

title: Luxury Homeowners Put a Ring on Jewel-Box Homes
summary: Newlyweds to empty-nesters are trading big, high maintenance homes for smaller square footage packed with high-end finishes. A miniature dachshund named Huey played a big part in Hunter Frick's decision to buy a 1,300-square-foot, 1970s ranch house in East Hampton, N.Y., instead of one of the many large newer homes he looked at. So did a fear of too many weekend guests.

summary: By some measures, the nearly $2 trillion valuation of Aramco only puts it in fairly middling company. The Prince may get his dream-sort of.

summary: Conservative Boris Johnson has plans costing billions; Labour's Jeremy Corbyn has even bigger ideas. BARNSLEY, England-The fiscal brakes are coming off.

title: Huawei Strikes German 5G Deal Despite Political Pushback
summary: Telefónica becomes the first operator in Germany to publicly commit to the Chinese vendor. BERLIN-Huawei Technologies Inc. secured a commitment to build part of Germany's 5G infrastructure, strengthening its position in Europe's largest economy despite calls from lawmakers to bar the Chinese company.

title: Suu Kyi Defends Myanmar Against Rohingya Genocide Allegations
summary: Former human-rights icon expresses faith in the country's military in international court at The Hague. Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi stood before the International Court of Justice and defended her country against genocide allegations, an image that will define the international legacy of the Nobel Peace Prize winner once feted for her fight against repression.

title: When Your Insurer Decides Your Home Isn't Worth the Risk
summary: Homeowners living in areas prone to fire- and hurricane-related damage face another risk: getting dropped by their insurance company. As if living through a string of deadly wildfires weren't bad enough, some California homeowners were further burned when their insurers wouldn't renew their fire-protection policies. In response, California last week announced a one-year moratorium forbidding insurers from dropping customers who live in or adjacent to ZIP Codes affected by recent wildfires.

title: Fed Adds $42 Billion in Overnight Liquidity
summary: Fed's intervention comes via overnight repurchase agreements. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $42 billion in one-day liquidity to financial markets Wednesday.

title: Vatican Uses Donations for the Poor to Plug Its Budget Deficit
summary: Only 10% of donations to the Peter's Pence collection go to charitable works. VATICAN CITY-Every year, Catholics around the world donate tens of millions of dollars to the pope. Bishops exhort the faithful to support the weak and suffering through the pope's main charitable appeal, called Peter's Pence.

title: Faculty Lounge Is Sanders Country
summary: Be grateful university professors don't choose our leaders.. Reader reaction to Monday's story on the near political monoculture among Yale faculty is consistent with this column's recent experience. Your humble correspondent has lately been struck by the number of people in conversation who cite politicized education as the country's biggest problem. Of course the problem goes way beyond Yale.

title: Germany Pushes Forward on European Financial Transactions Tax
summary: The tax would apply on trading of large cap stocks, such as BMW, Sanofi and Zara-owner Inditex. Germany, France, Italy and seven other countries are moving forward with a plan to impose a joint financial transaction tax on stock trading, an effort that has proved elusive in Europe.

title: Volkswagen Parent Acquires Stake in Self-Driving Startup
summary: Porsche SE invests in Aeva, capping a year of autonomous sector moves. Porsche Automobil Holding SE has acquired a minority stake in Silicon Valley self-driving sensor startup Aeva Inc., the latest in a flurry of moves by the auto manufacturing holding company in the autonomous driving sector this year.

title: Expect Fewer Big Media Deals Next Decade, Says Top Deal Maker
summary: LionTree CEO Aryeh Bourkoff says the biggest media companies won't need to make huge deals to build out their streaming services. One of the media industry's most prolific deal makers is predicting a slowdown in big acquisitions over the next decade.

title: The Curve Appeal of This Temple to Swiss Watches
summary: A new spiral-shaped museum for Audemars Piguet channels the Swiss watch brand's legacy of craftsmanship. There are two obvious ways to go about designing a museum for the venerable Swiss watchmaker Audemars Piguet, and each has obvious drawbacks. The first would be to go native. Audemars Piguet-best known for its Royal Oak model, the first luxury sports watch-was founded almost 150 years ago in the village of Le Brassus in the Joux Valley. The village hasn't changed all that much since then, and the locals clearly like it that way.

title: Bloomberg Woos Minority Voters in 2020 Bid
summary: 'Stop-and-frisk' continues to pop up in the former mayor's meetings with black leaders. In his first few events as a Democratic presidential candidate, billionaire Michael Bloomberg has huddled with black elected officials and activists in Mississippi, addressed a diverse gathering of party leaders in Texas and toured an African-American history museum in Georgia.

title: Christine Lagarde Needs to Be a Negotiator-But Also a Plumber
summary: The new head of the European Central Bank faces a herculean task in preparing the eurozone financial system for the next crisis. When U.S. money markets seized up in September, it was only a minor headache for Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell. Over at the European Central Bank, arcane details of market plumbing may end up becoming a key concern of new boss Christine Lagarde's mandate.

title: Lawmakers Deadlocked on Tax Breaks
summary: Despite agreement on an array of tax-policy items, a deal has proven elusive. title: How Rare Luggage Replaced Sneakers as the Latest It-Accessory
summary: Disrupter brands such as Arlo Skye and high-end collaborations by German brand Rimowa are making the airport a fashion runway. BUYING LUGGAGE used to be about as sexy as acquiring a refrigerator. You schlepped to Sears or, if you were feeling fancy, a Tumi boutique, and chose whichever carry-on could hold the most stuff without socks and underwear erupting through the zipper. Today, bagging a new roller-bag from the growing array of status-signifying models can feel more like scoring a pair of the latest buzzy Nikes. "Function kind of has become cool, so all of a sudden luggage has become one of the fastest-growing accessory categories," explained Beth Goldstein, the fashion footwear and accessories industry analyst at market-research firm NPD Group.

title: Poshmark CEO Wants You to 'Like' Your Secondhand Threads
summary: Manish Chandra discusses building a social network around shopping, the Marie Kondo effect and whether it's acceptable to gift used items. What happens when you mix eBay and Instagram, then add millions of fashionistas eager to shop each others' closets? You get Poshmark, the social-commerce platform founded by entrepreneur Manish Chandra.

title: North American Trade Pact Could Cushion U.S. Economy
summary: Economists say deal with Mexico, Canada removes business uncertainty, but won't bring any boom. WASHINGTON-The new trade agreement with Mexico and Canada won't bring an economic boom, but it could cushion the U.S. in the face of slowing global growth as it boosts some industries and removes a big source of business uncertainty.

title: Central Bank Group's Report Points to Deeper Problems in Repo Market
summary: BIS report says key repo lending activities have become concentrated in four firms that are keeping more of their liquidity in Treasurys. New research from the Bank for International Settlements counters the widely held view that short-term interest rates went wild in mid-September due mostly to a large Treasury debt settlement and corporate tax date, instead finding more complex forces at play in money markets.

title: CFOs Brace for Potential Recession in 2020
summary: Chief financial officers are cutting costs and hoarding cash to ride out an expected downturn.. Chief financial officers are bracing for a recession, cutting costs and hoarding cash to ride out an expected downturn ahead of next year's presidential election, new research indicates.

title: How One Israeli Town Heralds a National Political Crisis
summary: Tel Aviv suburb that tracks national trends is divided, auguring more national political gridlock. REHOVOT, Israel-This middle-class suburb near Tel Aviv has so closely tracked the country's national politics that it has become known as the Ohio of Israel.

title: Fed Likely to Hold Rates Steady After Busy Year
summary: Powell is expected to affirm the central bank's make-no-moves stance after cutting rates at three previous meetings. Federal Reserve officials are likely to hold their benchmark interest rate steady after their two-day meeting concludes Wednesday and aren't expected to make notable changes to their wait-and-see posture on more rate reductions.

title: Athletes Seeking Visas Find Proving They're Exceptional Has Gotten Tougher
summary: As the U.S. tightens immigration policies, foreigners face higher barriers to entry on the basis of 'extraordinary ability'. For foreign-born swimmers, jockeys, tennis players, gymnasts and ice dancers who want to work or live in the U.S., the toughest competition these days may be persuading the Trump administration they are extraordinary.

title: Japan and the Art of Making the Same Mistakes Over and Over Again
summary: A sales-tax increase has once again dented the Japanese economy more than the government expected; the country can do better. For the third time, Japan has increased the country's sales tax when a tightening of fiscal policy wasn't merited. For the third time, the economic hit has been greater than expected.

title: China's Housing Market Goes the WeWork Way-and Thousands Get Evicted
summary: 'Apartment operators' sign long-term leases with landlords and sublease to individuals, typically after renovating and partitioning. In China, a crowd of startups is looking to cash in on a hot real-estate market by disrupting the way apartments are rented.

title: New Jersey Kosher Store Target of Deadly Attack
summary: Authorities say a police officer was among those killed during a gunfight that started at a cemetery. JERSEY CITY, N.J.-Two gunmen went on an hourslong shooting rampage Tuesday, targeting a Jewish grocery store and getting into a firefight with police that killed four people, including a police officer, as well as the two suspects, officials said.

title: Federal Reserve Keeps Interest Rates Steady, Sees Long Pause
summary: Officials indicate comfort with leaving policy on hold through next year, while keeping eye on economy. WASHINGTON-The Federal Reserve held interest rates steady and signaled no appetite to raise them soon.

summary: New rule blocks birds from neighboring Benin, creating shortage; game of chicken on the border. LAGOS-One of the largest restaurant chains in the largest economy in Africa keeps running out of chicken. Its name is Chicken Republic.
